name: Irving Cheng
descriptions: Irving Cheng is an inhabitant of Tenpenny Tower in 2277, who is married to Tiffany Cheng.

Irving, a wealthy elderly man with a secret identity, believes himself to be the direct descendant of Chairman Cheng, the leader of the People's Republic of China before the War. Prideful of his assumed lineage, he insists on addressing himself and all others as "comrade," and is embarrassed by his own given name, as it fails to reflect his imagined heritage.

In his computer terminal, he writes that his father was one of the leading officers in the Chinese Army. He also writes about his "plans" for creating a communist society in Tenpenny Tower, which he terms the "Tenpenny Commune." Cheng heavily implies he is prejudiced against ghouls, as with many of the other Tenpenny residents.
Comrade Cheng can be overheard speaking with Susan Lancaster, revealing why his wife despises him so much. Comrade Cheng is also having an affair with Susan Lancaster.

topics.response_text: Aiiiyeeeeah! Get away from me!{in the middle of an attack against his town}

topics.topic_text: Do you know anything about the basement level, comrade?
topics.response_text: Only that they keep generators down there... and some kind of emergency escape tunnels.{trying to be helpful}

topics.topic_text: What's it like living at Tenpenny Tower?
topics.response_text: It's great. Now that we have a real comrade around here to handle things. I'm appointing a special Security Subcommittee and I want you to chair it!{(naively) self important but showing appreciation}

topics.topic_text: It's nice to meet someone with a sense of civic duty.
topics.response_text: Thanks, comrade. I'm sure you'll agree the people are only as strong as their leader. That's why I do my best to serve the community to the fullest.{naively self-important}

topics.topic_text: People don't need leaders, just good common sense.
topics.response_text: Ah, but not everyone has common sense. Do they?{naively self-important}
Not very bright, are you? Don't worry, comrade. Even the least of us have some small though important role to play in the community.{naively self-important}

topics.topic_text: It will take more than a committee to deal with the problem. I think I can help.
topics.response_text: That's wonderful, comrade! Truly wonderful! Before you go Ghoul hunting, talk to Gustavo. He might be able to help you.{happy to finally have a hero}

topics.topic_text: Committees won't help. You need to simply ignore them, or exterminate them.
topics.response_text: Well, I'll try to not be bothered then... and perhaps you should speak to comrade Gustavo about getting rid of them altogether.{mildly dejected}

topics.topic_text: Don't worry about those Ghouls, comrade. You need to relax.
topics.response_text: Perhaps you're right. My wife is always going on about how crazy I make her.{a little depressed and ashamed}

topics.topic_text: What's it like living at Tenpenny Tower?
topics.response_text: Well comrade, things are great. The best of the best have made a community here.{naively self important}

topics.topic_text: What do you think of the whole situation with the Ghouls?
topics.response_text: I'm sure it will end in bloodshed. It's serious business, comrade.{nervous}

topics.topic_text: I think I can help with your Ghoul problem...
topics.response_text: Excellent. Speak with comrade Gustavo. He'll know what to do.{glad someone is taking charge}

topics.topic_text: Perhaps, comrade, the Ghouls will join your committee, comrade.
topics.response_text: Are you mocking me, comrade?{self important indignation}
That's not the word I'd use for it, comrade.{bored by the conversation}

topics.topic_text: How would you feel about having a few Ghoul neighbors?
topics.response_text: You've finally got around to asking me, comrade.{hesitant but sincere}

topics.topic_text: It's wise to be afraid of Ghouls.
topics.response_text: Indeed, comrade. Indeed. I wonder though, if they might also need their own community?{snob losing prejudice}

topics.topic_text: Comrade, I've met these ghouls. They seem friendly enough. More than this lot.
topics.response_text: Well, perhaps you're right, comrade. Some of these folk have a few things to learn about camaraderie, that's for sure.{letting go of prejudice}

topics.topic_text: Would you tell Mister Tenpenny that you wouldn't mind Ghoul neighbors?
topics.response_text: Alright, comrade. We'll welcome them into the community.
I have something to do, comrade. If you'll excuse me...{trying to get out of the conversation}

conversation.response_text: I wouldn't know. She's avoiding me lately.{sad}
Oh, I don't know. Not so good I guess... Women. Can't live with them. Can't live without them. Know what I mean, Comrade?{dejected}
Right, comrade! I see. The fabulous comes from the inside out. I will have to remember that. Thank you!{grateful}
Ohhh. Well, comrade. I don't think I'll ever be able to do that.{despondent he can't make his wife happy.}
I'm hungry.{hungry and on his way to get food}
I'm tired. I'm going to bed.{tired and heading off to bed}
SHE never yells at me. SHE appreciates me. Unlike some people.{to himself under his breath, thinking about his mistress}
Are you alright, Comrade?{confused and slightly suspicious}
